mitigation_action: Install or retrofit stormwater treatment systems to reduce pollutant runoff.
Restore riparian vegetation buffers along streambanks to filter contaminants.
Restrict use of nutrient-rich fertilizers near water bodies.
Implement rain gardens and bioswales in surrounding landscapes.
Inspect and maintain septic systems to prevent leakage into freshwater systems.
Encourage public education on reducing household runoff and water use.
Monitor freshwater quality bi-annually and report anomalies.
Implement Mechanical Control: Hand-pulling, mowing, cutting, prescribed burns.
Biological control via approved insects (e.g., weevil Ceutorhynchus scrobicollis for garlic mustard).
Chemical control via herbicides with NJDEP permit & certified applicator.
Target small populations manually to reduce habitat disturbance.
Eradicate alien herbivores (e.g., rabbits, pigs) in isolated biodiversity-rich areas.
Use biological agents only after screening and monitoring; avoid persistent chemicals.
Use native dense planting to outcompete invasive species.
Avoid herbicide use near aquatic systems; favor manual/mechanical methods.
Control early before population gets large to reduce costs and habitat damage.
For invasive vertebrates: use buffer crops, zoning, nighttime enclosures, and prey base management.
Consider assisted colonization in line with IUCN Conservation Translocation Group protocols
Implement zoning, buffer crops, livestock fencing, and night enclosures
Prioritize rescue and return to original range, avoid translocation if possible
Reintroduce near original habitat to minimize genetic and disease risk to local populations
Use hazing, improve natural prey base, or relocate human communities
Follow WOAH sanitary protocols during care, transport, and release
Establish Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) to limit human interference in high-risk zones. Enforce seasonal restrictions on commercial fishing and offshore drilling activities.
Mandate the use of low-impact marine vessels and enforce no-discharge zones to reduce pollution in sensitive marine habitats.
Implement mandatory marine spatial planning tools to balance marine recreation, fishing, and conservation priorities.
Promote green port initiatives to reduce harbor and vessel pollution (e.g., cold-ironing, alternative fuels).
Conduct periodic monitoring of marine water quality and promote stakeholder education in coastal communities.
Encourage sustainable tourism and habitat restoration grants for small-scale coastal conservation projects.
